channel.title: AP Statistics Review Material on
channel.description: Recent content in AP Statistics Review Material on

item.description: Correlation Correlation expresses the extent to which two variables are related (change proportionally). Correlation $\neq$ Linear Relationship Note that correlations don’t always have to be linear relationships!
Linear Models Linear models, also called a line of best fit are used to predict response values from explanatory values in a bivariate distribution.

item.title: Chi-Squared Test for Goodness-Of-Fit
item.description: The $\chi^2$ test for goodness-of-fit is a test that compares the counts of an observed distribution of a single categorical variable to the expected distribution.

item.title: Chi-Squared Test for Homogeneity
item.description: A test for homogeneity tests whether one categorical variable is the same over two populations.

item.title: Chi-Squared Test for Independence
item.description: A test of independence examines the association between two variables in a single population. Hypotheses $H_0$: Variables are independent of each other There is no association between row variable vs.

item.title: Five-Number Summary
item.description: The five-number summary of a dataset consists of the following: minimum value first/lower quartile ($Q_1$) median third/upper quartile ($Q_3$) maximum value You can get these values from One-Variable Statistics on your calculator.

item.title: Linear Regression T-Test
item.description: Linear regression $t$ tests are used to quantify the relationship between a predictor variable and a response variable. Whenever we perform a linear regression, we want to know if there is a statistically significant relationship between the predictor variable and the response variable.

item.title: Measures of Center for Quantitative Distributions
item.description: There are two primary measures of center, mean and median. Mode, which is the most commonly occurring value in the distribution, may be seen.

item.title: Measures of Spread for Quantitative Distributions
item.description: There are multiple values that can represent the spread of the distribution. Variance and [[Standard Deviation]] The [[standard deviation]] is defined as the typical difference between a value in the distribution and the average for the distribution.

item.title: Normal Distribution
item.description: For important calculator functions, see [[Normal Distribution Calculator Functions]]. ![[Normal Distribution Model.png]] The normal distribution is a type of [[Quantitative Data|continuous]] probability distribution for a random variable.

item.title: Normal Distribution Calculator Functions
item.description: Normal Cumulative Distribution Function The normal cumulative distribution function (normCdf) can find the proportion of the area under the normal curve that lies between two values in the normal distribution.

item.title: Qualitative Data
item.description: Qualitative data, or categorical data, are data that can be classified into a group based on a non-numerical characteristic. Note that some data can be numerical, but qualitative.

item.title: Quantitative Data
item.description: Quantitative data, or numerical data are measures or counts. Discrete and Continuous Variables Discrete variables are variables that are distinct, separated values.

item.title: Shapes of Quantitative Distributions
item.description: Describing the shape of a quantitative distribution consists of two parts: Skew Modality Skew If the graph is symmetric when using the middle of the graph as the line of reflection, the graph is approximately normal.

item.title: Standard Deviation
item.description: The standard deviation is defined as the typical difference between a value in the distribution and the average for the distribution.

item.title: Unit 1 - One-Variable Data Analysis
item.description: Parameters & Statistics Values that describe a sample are called statistics, and values that describe a population are called parameters.

item.title: Unit 2 - Two-Variable Data Analysis
item.description: Two-variable (or bivariate) [[Quantitative Data|quantitative data]] is data where we compare two different variables, and whether there is a [[Correlation|correlation]] between the two variables.

item.title: Unit 8 - Inference for Categorical Data for Chi-Square
item.description: $\chi^2$ Models $\chi^2$ models are used to compare counts of categorical data when comparing the observed distribution(s) to the expected distribution(s) of data.

item.title: Unusual Features of a Quantitative Distribution
item.description: Distributions can have many unusual features, which can affect descriptions and generalizations of the distributions. Outliers An outlier is a value in the distribution that is extremely far away from the rest of the points in the distribution.

item.title: Z-Scores
item.description: The $z$-score is simply a measure of how many standard deviations away a certain value in a distribution is from the mean.
